title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #648: Decreasing Greatest Prime Factors**

Let g(n) be the longest increasing sequence below n with strictly decreasing greatest prime factors.

**Status**: SOLVED (Cambie)

**Answer**: g(n) ≍ (n/log n)^(1/2)

title: GPF Axiom
content:
**gpfAx n**: Axiomatized greatest prime factor.

The largest prime that divides n, axiomatized for simplicity.

title: Greatest Prime Factor
content:
**gpf n**: P(n) = greatest prime factor of n.

Returns 0 if n ≤ 1, otherwise uses gpfAx.

title: GPF of One
content:
**gpf_one**: P(1) = 0 by convention.

Base case for the greatest prime factor function.

title: GPF of Zero
content:
**gpf_zero**: P(0) = 0 by convention.

Base case for the greatest prime factor function.

title: GPF of Prime
content:
**gpf_prime**: P(p) = p for any prime p.

The only prime factor of a prime is itself.

title: GPF Divides
content:
**gpf_dvd**: P(n) | n for n > 1.

The greatest prime factor divides the number.

title: GPF is Prime
content:
**gpf_is_prime**: P(n) is prime for n > 1.

By definition of prime factorization.

title: GPF is Maximum
content:
**gpf_max**: Any prime dividing n is ≤ P(n).

P(n) is the maximum prime factor.

title: GPF-Descending Sequence
content:
**isGPFDescendingSeq seq**: A sequence is GPF-descending if values are strictly increasing while GPFs are strictly decreasing.

This is the central structure of the problem.

title: Valid GPF Sequence
content:
**isValidGPFSeq n seq**: A GPF-descending sequence where all elements are in [2, n).

Valid sequences are bounded below n.

title: Function g(n)
content:
**g n**: Maximum length of a valid GPF-descending sequence below n.

This is the extremal function the problem asks about.

title: Example: [3, 4]
content:
**example_3_4_gpf_descending**: P(3) > P(4), i.e., 3 > 2.

The pair [3, 4] has increasing values but decreasing GPF.

title: Example: [7, 9, 16]
content:
**example_7_9_16_gpf_descending**: P(7) > P(9) > P(16).

A length-3 GPF-descending sequence: 7 > 3 > 2.

title: Example: Length 4
content:
**example_length_4_exists**: [7, 10, 27, 64] has P values [7, 5, 3, 2].

A length-4 GPF-descending sequence.

title: Lower Bounds on g(n)
content:
**g_ge_one, g_ge_two, g_ge_three, g_ge_four**:
- g(n) ≥ 1 for n ≥ 3
- g(n) ≥ 2 for n ≥ 5
- g(n) ≥ 3 for n ≥ 17
- g(n) ≥ 4 for n ≥ 65

title: Smooth Numbers
content:
**isSmooth B n**: n is B-smooth if P(n) ≤ B.

Smooth numbers have bounded greatest prime factor.

title: Powers of 2 Smooth
content:
**power_of_two_smooth**: 2^k is 2-smooth for k ≥ 1.

Powers of 2 have the smallest possible GPF.

title: Prime Power Smooth
content:
**prime_power_smooth**: p^k is p-smooth for prime p.

Prime powers are smooth with respect to that prime.

title: Cambie's Lower Bound
content:
**cambie_lower_bound**: g(n) ≥ c₁ · √(n/log n) for some c₁ ≥ 2.

Explicit construction achieves this bound.

title: Cambie's Upper Bound
content:
**cambie_upper_bound**: g(n) ≤ c₂ · √(n/log n) for some c₂ ≤ 2√2.

The key is counting smooth numbers appropriately.

title: Cambie's Main Result
content:
**cambie_main**: g(n) ≍ (n/log n)^(1/2).

Both lower and upper bounds of order √(n/log n).

The main result solving Erdős #648.

title: Asymptotic Conjecture
content:
**cambie_asymptotic_conjecture**: Does g(n)/√(n/log n) → c for some c ∈ [2, 2√2]?

Asks whether the limit exists.

title: Constant Bounds
content:
**c_lower** = 2
**c_upper** = 2√2 ≈ 2.83

Bounds on the potential asymptotic constant.

title: Upper Bound < 3
content:
**c_upper_lt_three**: 2√2 < 3.

Verifies the upper bound constant is less than 3.

title: Prime Power Sequence
content:
**primePowerSequence**: Example construction using [7, 10, 27, 64].

Demonstrates the construction strategy.

title: Smallest Prime Factor
content:
**spf n**: The smallest prime dividing n.

Dual to greatest prime factor.

title: SPF ≤ GPF
content:
**spf_le_gpf**: p(n) ≤ P(n) for n > 1.

Smallest prime factor is at most the greatest.

title: SPF = GPF for Primes
content:
**spf_eq_gpf_prime**: p(p) = P(p) = p for primes.

Primes have a unique prime factor.

title: Summary Theorem
content:
**erdos_648_summary**: Combines lower and upper bounds.

States the full result with both directions.

title: Main Result
content:
**erdos_648**: Erdős Problem #648 is SOLVED.

Question: What is the asymptotic behavior of g(n)?

Answer: g(n) ≍ (n/log n)^(1/2)

Solved by Stijn Cambie.

title: Length 4 Verification
content:
**length_four_exists**: Concrete verification that [7, 10, 27, 64] is a valid length-4 GPF-descending sequence below 100.

All conditions verified explicitly.
